questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with specific difficulties in her left hand. She reports difficulty extending the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint of her middle finger and flexing at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following deformities is most consistent with the patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Articular deformity and changes in rheumatoid arthritis

Articular changes

Autoimmune inflammation mediates pannus formation, eroding the articular cartilage and bone.

Metacarpophalangeal joint (MCP), proximal interphalangeal joint and wrist joint are involved

Deformities

 

 

Swan neck deformity (Option B)

  • Extension at proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP)
  • Flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP): The DIP joint is not involved; flexion occurs due to tension on the tendons attached to the base of Distal phalanges

Boutonniere deformity (Option A ruled out)

  • Flexion at PIP and extension at DIP
  • Both swan neck and boutonniere deformity can occur in different fingers of the same hand.

Z-line deformity (Option C ruled out)

  • Subluxation of the first metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • Hyperextension of interphalangeal joint.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of asthma presents with worsening dyspnea, peripheral neuropathy, and palpable purpura on his lower limbs. He also has a history of sinusitis. Blood tests reveal marked eosinophilia and a positive p-ANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man presents with recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and bilateral uveitis. He develops pustules 48 hours after the needle prick. Further examination reveals erythema nodosum and non-erosive arthritis of the knees. Based on clinical criteria, Behcet's Disease is diagnosed. Which of the following represents the most appropriate initial management strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: High-dose steroids alone for all manifestations

options.label: B
options.text: Targeted therapy based on organ involvement: colchicine for mucocutaneous, topical steroids for anterior uveitis

questions.correct_answer: B. Targeted therapy based on organ involvement: colchicine for mucocutaneous, topical steroids for anterior uveitis
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria (ITR-ICBD)

Two Points Each:

  • Genital aphthosis
  • Ocular lesions
 

One Point Each:

  • Oral aphthosis
  • Skin lesions
  • Vascular manifestations
  • Positive pathergy

≥3 points needed for diagnosis

Laboratory Findings
  • Non-specific inflammation markers
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • ESR, CRP elevation
  • Leukocytosis

Helps rule out other conditions

Required Investigations
  • Ophthalmologic examination
  • Pathergy test
  • Skin biopsy if needed
  • Imaging, based on symptoms

Confirms involvement and monitors complications

Treatment

Mucocutaneous Treatment
  • Colchicine 1-2mg/day
  • Topical steroids
  • Topical sucralfate

Refractory: Systemic steroids, azathioprine

Ocular Treatment
  • Anterior: Topical steroids
  • Posterior: Steroids + azathioprine

Refractory: TNF inhibitors

Major Organ Involvement
  • Vascular: High-dose steroids + cyclophosphamide
  • Neurologic: High-dose steroids + immunosuppression

Requires aggressive therapy and monitoring

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with fever, rash, and strawberry tongue. The child has circumoral pallor and a sandpaper-like rash. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated inflammatory markers. Which of the following statements is most likely to be true regarding this presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: IVIG with high-dose aspirin is the first-line treatment

options.label: B
options.text: The rash begins over the face and shows circumoral erythema

options.label: C
options.text: Throat culture is essential for diagnosis and Penicillin is the treatment of choice

options.label: D
options.text: Coronary artery involvement is seen in the majority of untreated cases

questions.correct_answer: C. Throat culture is essential for diagnosis and Penicillin is the treatment of choice
questions.explanation:
Feature

Kawasaki’s Disease

Scarlet Fever

Cause

Etiology unknown; Likely Immune-Mediated.

Group A Streptococcus infection (Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins A, B, C).

Age Group Affected
  • It primarily affects children,
  • 80% of cases in children ≤5 years old,
  • Peak incidence at ≤2 years.

Most common in children aged 2–10 years, usually following Group A streptococcal pharyngitis.

Main Symptoms

Based on fever lasting ≥5 days + ≥4 of 5 principal criteria:

  • Fever ≥5 days
  • Bilateral conjunctival injection (red eyes)
  • Oral mucosal changes (strawberry tongue, red lips)
  • Rash (polymorphous)
  • Extremity changes (swelling, redness, peeling)
  • Fever,
  • Pharyngitis,
  • Headache,
  • Characteristic rash with a sandpaper-like texture, beginning on the face, spreading to the trunk and extremities, sparing palms and soles, followed by desquamation.
  • Circumoral pallor, and
  • Strawberry tongue.

Other Symptoms

Coronary artery aneurysms,

myocarditis, pericarditis, myocardial ischemia, infarction, cardiomegaly.

Rash accentuates in skin folds (Pastia’s lines), desquamation in the second week.

Complications
  • Coronary Artery Aneurysms
  • Myocardial Infarction
  • Thrombosis
  • Vasculitis.
  • Rheumatic Fever
  • Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis

Diagnostic method

Diagnosis is clinical based on criteria and confirmed by echocardiogram for coronary artery changes.

Throat culture or RADT (Rapid Antigen Detection Test) for Group A Streptococcus confirmation.

Treatment
  • High-dose IV Immunoglobulin and Aspirin to reduce coronary artery complications.
  • In severe cases, surgical intervention may be required (e.g., coronary artery bypass grafting).
  • Antibiotics (penicillin or amoxicillin),
  • Supportive care for fever and throat pain.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female presents with a new-onset headache, jaw claudication, and visual symptoms. Her ESR is 92 mm/hr and CRP is elevated. Temporal artery biopsy is planned, but immediate treatment is necessary. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: Wait for biopsy results before starting any treatment

questions.text: Match each condition with its corresponding key synovial fluid characteristics: Conditions Key Characteristics 1. Normal a. Yellow, Cloudy, >50,000 WBC 2. Non-inflammatory b. Colorless, Clear, <200 WBC 3. Inflammatory c. Yellow, Opaque, Positive Gram Stain 4. Septic d. Xanthochromic or Red, Bloody 5. Hemarthrosis e. Straw-like, Clear, 200 - 2000 WBC

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents with severe pain in his right big toe, redness, and swelling, as shown in the image. He has a history of hypertension and recently increased her consumption of red meat. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiological process leading to her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased renal tubular secretion of uric acid

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired renal excretion of uric acid

questions.correct_answer: C. Impaired renal excretion of uric acid

questions.text: A 35 y/o female with ankylosing spondylitis is experiencing episodes of uveitis. Which would be the most appropriate drug to address both her uveitis and her underlying condition?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Ankylosing Spondylitis

Non-Pharmacological Measures

Exercises for improving posture, flexibility, and muscle strength.

Pharmacological Therapy

Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs)

First-line treatment to treat pain and inflammation.

Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drugs (DMARDs)

Sulfasalazine is used for peripheral arthritis

Methotrexate is less effective in ankylosing spondylitis.

TNF Inhibitors
  • It reduces inflammation and is effective for both axial and peripheral symptoms.
  • Examples: Infliximab, Etanercept, Adalimumab, Golimumab, Certolizumab Pegol.
  • Adalimumab has been FDA-approved for managing uveitis. It can control both spinal symptoms and uveitis episodes in the patient.

IL-17A Inhibitors

Secukinumab

Effective in patients who have not tolerated anti-TNF therapy

Glucocorticoids

Can be used in attacks of uveitis.

Janus Kinase (JAK) Inhibitors

Tofacitinib, Upadacitinib, and Filgotinib show efficacy in clinical trials.

questions.text: Match the following: 1. Swan neck deformity a)  2. Boutonniere deformity b) 3. Z-line deformity c) 4. Mallet finger deformity d)
questions.explanation:
Deformities

Images

Swan neck deformity

  • Extension at proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP)
  • Flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP): The DIP joint is not involved; flexion occurs due to tension on the tendons attached to the base of Distal phalanges

Boutonniere deformity

  • Flexion at PIP and extension at DIP
  • Both swan neck and boutonniere deformity can occur in different fingers of the same hand.

Z-line deformity

  • Subluxation of the first metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • Hyperextension of interphalangeal joint.

Mallet finger deformity

  • Inability to extend the DIP joint due to a tendon injury without affecting the PIP joint.
  • It is usually a sports injury and is not seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with significant joint pain, stiffness, and swelling affecting multiple joints. Her Disease Activity Score (DAS28) is 5.4, indicating high disease activity. She has not responded adequately to lifestyle modifications and NSAIDs. Which medication is considered this patient's first-line disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD)?
questions.explanation:
• The DAS score typically ranges from 0 to 10.
    • Low Disease Activity: DAS < 3.2
    • Moderate Disease Activity: DAS 3.2 - 5.1
    • High Disease Activity: DAS > 5.1
  • A decrease in the DAS score indicates improvement, while an increase suggests worsening disease activity.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with bilateral pain, swelling, and stiffness in his hands and wrists for the past 4 months. His symptoms are worse in the morning and improve throughout the day. The physical exam shows synovitis in the metacarpophalangeal joints. Considering the high specificity for rheumatoid arthritis, which initial investigation is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
To establish diagnosis

  • Clinical criteria
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)
  • Ultrasound or magnetic resonance imaging (Option D ruled out)
  • ACPA and RF (both are positive in about 70% of the cases)

To monitor disease damage

  • X-rays
  • Functional assessment

To monitor disease activity and drug efficacy

  • Pain (visual analogue scale)
  • Early morning stiffness (minutes)
  • Joint tenderness
  • Joint swelling
  • DAS28 score (Disease activity score 28)
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein

To monitor drug safety

  • Urinalysis
  • Full blood count
  • Chest X-ray
  • Urea and creatinine
  • Liver function test

questions.text: A 45 y/o woman presents with progressive muscle weakness and a distinctive rash on her eyelids and knuckles. She also exhibits a rash like in the given image. She reports difficulty swallowing and has experienced some joint pain. Which of the following statements about this patient's condition is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: The rash may precede or accompany the muscle weakness.

options.label: B
options.text: Weakness is typically asymmetric, affecting distal muscles more than proximal.

options.label: C
options.text: Nail bed telangiectasias are a common finding.

options.label: D
options.text: Patients may present with only a rash and no muscle weakness.

questions.correct_answer: B. Weakness is typically asymmetric, affecting distal muscles more than proximal.
questions.explanation:
Heliotrope rash
 

Gottron’s Papules

Shawl sign

V Sign

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with episodes of sequential color changes in her fingers (white, blue, and red) triggered by cold exposure. She has no underlying conditions, normal nail fold capillaroscopy, and symmetric involvement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Primary

Secondary

Age of Onset

Younger (<30 years)

Older (>30 years)

Nail fold capillaries

Normal

Large tortuous

Autoantibodies

Negative to low

Frequent

Endothelial damage

No

Frequent

Digital gangrene

Rare

Frequent

Occlusions

No

Yes

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has been suffering from a persistent cough, progressive shortness of breath, and fatigue for the past several months. A chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. The patient also has a skin rash, as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements regarding this patient's diagnosis is false?

options.label: B
options.text: PET scan indicates increased metabolic activity.

questions.correct_answer: C. CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio in BAL < 3.5.
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Features

Chest X-ray
  • Stage I: Hilar lymphadenopathy + right paratracheal lymphadenopathy
  • Stage II: Adenopathy + infiltrates
  • Stage III: Infiltrates
  • Stage IV: Fibrosis

 

Chest X-ray and Gross specimen showing Hilar lymphadenopathy

HRCT
  • Reticulonodular opacities (galaxy sign) in a perilymphatic distribution, often centred on broncho-vascular bundles and subpleural areas (Option A)

​​​

Spirometry
  • FEV / FVC <0.7- Airway stenosis

DLCO
  • Reduced

PET scan > MRI > Gallium-67 scan
  • For diagnosis of extra pulmonary sarcoidosis
  • PET scan reveals increased metabolic activities in areas of inflammation. (Option B)

Biochemical findings
  • Lymphopenia
  • Elevated ACE levels.
  • Hypercalcemia may reflect increased calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D) production by alveolar macrophages.
  • Hypercalciuria can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Liver Function Tests are mildly deranged in granulomatous involvement of the liver.

Biopsy
  • Non-caseating granulomas seen in biopsies from pulmonary or extrapulmonary organs confirm the diagnosis. (Option D ruled out)

Bronchoscopy

May demonstrate a "cobblestone" appearance of the mucosa.

Bronchoalveolar lavage

Lymphocytosis,CD4:CD8 >3.5

Endobronchial Ultrasound (EBUS)
  • Assists in diagnosing sarcoidosis in patients with mediastinal adenopathy.
  • Can be combined with transbronchial biopsy to improve diagnostic yield.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female complains of morning stiffness lasting over an hour and pain in her hands and wrists. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness of multiple small joints in her hands. Laboratory results show a positive rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies. X-ray reveals soft tissue swelling and early joint space narrowing. Which of the following joint involvement patterns is most characteristic of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Symmetrical involvement of small joints, particularly the MCP and PIP joints

options.label: B
options.text: Asymmetrical involvement of small joints, particularly the MCP and PIP joints

options.label: C
options.text: Symmetrical involvement of the DIP joints

options.label: D
options.text: Asymmetrical involvement of the DIP joints

questions.correct_answer: A. Symmetrical involvement of small joints, particularly the MCP and PIP joints
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)

Osteoarthritis (OA)

Psoriatic Arthritis

Gout

Reactive Arthritis

Joint Involvement Pattern

Symmetrical involvement of small joints (MCP, PIP)

Asymmetrical involvement, especially DIP joints (Option D ruled out)

Asymmetrical involvement, often DIP joints

Typically involves a single joint (e.g., big toe)

Asymmetrical involvement, often larger joints

Morning Stiffness

Lasts over 1 hour

Resolves within 30 minutes

Varies, often significant

Rarely significant

Variable often follows infection

Key Symptoms

Swelling, tenderness, deformities (e.g., ulnar deviation)

Pain and stiffness with use

Dactylitis, nail changes

Sudden, severe pain and swelling

Joint pain following an infection

Affected Joints

MCP, PIP, wrists, knees

Knees, hips, hands (DIP, PIP)

MCP, PIP, and can include spine and tendons

Typically big toe (1st MTP joint)

Larger joints (e.g., knees, ankles)

Radiographic Findings

Soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing

Osteophytes, joint space narrowing

Erosions, possible nail changes

Erosions and tophi possible

Similar to RA but typically larger joints

questions.text: A 30 y/o woman presents with a persistent cough, fatigue, and painful red nodules on her lower legs. Her ACE levels were found to be elevated and her chest x-ray findings are given below. She has a family history of autoimmune diseases and carries the HLA-DRB1*03 haplotype. What pathophysiological feature is most likely contributing to her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Accumulation of neutrophils and eosinophils in lung tissue.

options.label: B
options.text: Interaction between antigen-presenting cells and T-helper cells leading to granuloma formation.

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased production of cytokines such as IL-2 and IFN-γ.

options.label: D
options.text: High levels of cyclosporine in the serum affecting T-cell activity.

questions.correct_answer: B. Interaction between antigen-presenting cells and T-helper cells leading to granuloma formation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent miscarriages, having experienced three miscarriages before 10 weeks of gestation and an unprovoked deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her left leg six months ago, which required anticoagulation therapy. She is diagnosed with antiphospholipid syndrome. Which of the following is not a diagnostic criterion of antiphospholipid syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Vascular thrombosis of artery, vein or any small vessel

options.label: B
options.text: 3 or more unexplained consecutive miscarriages before 10 weeks of gestation

options.label: C
options.text: Positive titer for APLA antibodies on a single occasion

options.label: D
options.text: One or more unexplained deaths of a normal fetus at or after 10 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. Positive titer for APLA antibodies on a single occasion
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome

Clinical criteria

  • Vascular thrombosis - one or more clinical episodes of arterial, venous or small vessel thrombosis (Option A ruled out)
  • Pregnancy morbidity (anyone)
    • One or more unexplained deaths of a normal fetus at or after 10 weeks of gestation (Option D ruled out)
    • One or more premature births of a normal neonate before 34 weeks of gestation due to eclampsia, severe pre-eclampsia or placental insufficiency
    • Three or more unexplained consecutive miscarriages before 10 weeks of gestation (Option B ruled out)

Lab criteria

Intermediate or high titer of any one of the following antibodies on two occasions 12 weeks apart. (Option C)

  • Lupus antibody
  • Anticardiolipin
  • Anti-beta-2-glycoprotein-I

Diagnosis of APLA: One clinical + one laboratory criterion in the absence of other thrombophilia

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with TB on ATT isoniazid therapy presents with fatigue, fever, joint pain, and a rash. Laboratory tests reveal a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test, and anti-histone antibodies are detected. Which of the following ANA staining patterns is most likely found in this patient?
questions.explanation:
ANA patterns of SLE

ANA pattern

Antibody identifies

Clinical significance

Diffuse pattern

Histones

Significant for drug-induced lupus

Peripheral (rim) pattern

Anti-ds-DNA

Highly specific for SLE but not very sensitive

Speckled pattern (Option B ruled out)

Anti U1-RNP

Associated with mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)

Anti Sm

Is specific for Lupus

Anti Ro (SS-A)

Associated with Sjögren’s, SCLE & neonatal lupus.

Anti La (SS-B)

Associated with Anti-Ro

Anti Scl-70

Associated with diffuse scleroderma

Anti Jo-1

Associated with polymyositis with pneumonitis and arthritis

Nucleolar pattern

(Option C ruled out)

RNA polymerase

Associated with progressive systemic sclerosis

Centromere

(Option D ruled out)

Kinetochore

Associated with CREST, Sjogren’s & thyroiditis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presents with fever, rash, and joint pain. Laboratory tests show positive ANA and anti-histone antibodies. She has no signs of renal or neurological involvement. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for her symptoms?

A 25-year-old woman presents with fatigue, a malar rash, and joint pain. Laboratory tests show positive anti-dsDNA, anti-Smith antibodies, and a positive ANA. She undergoes a renal biopsy that reveals features consistent with lupus nephritis. Based on the SLICC criteria, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Four clinical criteria must be met to confirm SLE

options.label: B
options.text: Renal biopsy indicating lupus with lupus autoantibodies is sufficient

options.label: C
options.text: At least 2 clinical criteria with one antibody confirms SLE

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of Anti-ds, Anti-Sm and ANA confirms SLE

questions.correct_answer: B. Renal biopsy indicating lupus with lupus autoantibodies is sufficient

Systemic Lupus International Collaborating Clinic (SLICC) Criteria

Clinical Manifestations

Immunological Manifestations

Skin:

  • Low serum complement (C3, C4, or CH50)
  • Positive direct Coombs test
  • Oral or nasal ulcers
  • Nonscarring alopecia
  • Synovitis involving ≥2 joints
  • Serositis (Pleurisy or pericarditis)

Renal:

  • Protein-to-creatinine ratio (Prot/Cr) ≥0.5
  • RBC casts
  • Renal biopsy indicating lupus (Wire-loop lesions)

Neurologic:

  • Seizures
  • Psychosis
  • Mononeuritis & myelitis
  • Peripheral/Cranial neuropathies
  • Acute confusional state

Hematology:

  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Leukopenia (<4000/μL)
  • Lymphopenia (<1000/μL)
  • Thrombocytopenia (<100,000/μL)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with joint pain and skin rashes after being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a recent infection. She has a history of Systemic lupus erythematosus. Laboratory tests reveal positive anti-dsDNA antibodies. Which of the following antibodies would be more specific for diagnosing the cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Autoantibodies of SLE

Antibodies

Antigen recognised

Clinical significance

ANA

Multiple nuclear antigens

Best screening test for diagnosis, it is highly sensitive but not very specific for SLE.

Anti-dsDNA

DNA (double-stranded)

High titers are specific for SLE

Used to correlate with disease severity

Anti-C1q

(Option C ruled out)

Collagen-like determinants on C1q

Associated with active lupus nephritis, it is non-specific for SLE and can be used to correlate with disease activity. Deficiency predisposes SLE.

Anti-Sm

Protein complexed to 6 species of nuclear U1 RNA.

It is highly specific for SLE.

Anti-RNP (Option B ruled out)

Protein complexed to U1 RNA

Non-specific to SLE and is associated with syndromes that overlap with rheumatic syndromes

Anti-Ro (SS-A) (Option A ruled out)

Protein complexed to hY RNA 9 (primarily 60 kDa and 52 kDa)

Not very specific, it is associated with sicca syndrome and neonatal lupus (congenital heart block)

Anti-La (SS-B)

47-kDa protein complexed to hY RNA

Commonly associated with Anti-Ro antibody

Antihistone

Histones associated with DNA

Associated with drug-induced lupus.

Antiphospholipid

Phospholipids, β2-glycoprotein 1 cofactor, prothrombin

Usually predisposes to clotting, fetal loss and thrombocytopenia.

Anti Erythrocyte

Erythrocyte membrane

Causes autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

Antiplatelet

Surface and altered cytoplasmic antigens on platelets

It contributes to thrombocytopenia, is not very specific or sensitive, and is not used in regular practice.

Antineuronal antibody

Neuronal and lymphocyte surface antigens

Occasionally, it shows a positive correlation with active CNS lupus.

Anti Ribosomal P

Protein in ribosomes

Associated with neuropsychiatric manifestations.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female presents with a history of persistent dry mouth and a gritty sensation in her eyes. Her clinical evaluation is significant for dry mucous membranes and parotid gland swelling. A labial salivary gland biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination reveals inflammatory infiltration. Based on the histopathological findings in the provided image, which of the following features would most specifically support a diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Lymphocytic foci surrounding ducts with a focus score ≥ 1 per 4 mm² area

questions.correct_answer: B. Lymphocytic foci surrounding ducts with a focus score ≥ 1 per 4 mm² area

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis presents with worsening dyspnea and reduced lung function tests showing a restrictive pattern. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment choice?
questions.explanation:
Disease-modifying agents
  • Cyclophosphamide - for ILD
  • Mycophenolate mofetil - for skin and lung involvement
  • Tocilizumab - for skin and lung involvement
  • Nintedanib - for SSC-ILD

Vascular therapy
  • Calcium channel blockers - for Raynaud's
  • Angiotensin II receptor blockers
  • Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors
  • Bosentan - for digital ulcers

Novel therapies
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) for severe cases
  • Rituximab
